Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Shared pollinators affect flowering plant coexistence
Award.AbstractNarration:
Without pollinators like bees, bats and butterflies, most of the world's flowering plants would disappear. Because of the importance of pollinators, insuring their health is essential for preserving biodiversity and promoting global agricultural security. As pollinators, some native bees can show strong loyalty by limiting their visits to only flowers from a certain species, while other bees may not be so loyal, visiting many different types of flowers. In theory, plants with loyal pollinators should produce more fruit and seeds because the pollinators provide only the appropriate pollen type when they visit. The aim of this research is to understand the degree to which native bees show loyalty to certain plants. This study also explores how the sharing of pollinators between closely related plants might influence how many seeds those plants produce. If some of the plants do worse than others when sharing pollinators, differences in pollinator loyalty may influence how common or rare those plants become. The results of this research are important for understanding the role pollinators play in maintaining healthy and diverse agricultural and natural plant communities. This research contributes to the training of a graduate student, develops a lab and field program for a high school biology class and provides opportunities to engage and encourage women and under-represented students in STEM science.

Coexistence theory addresses how species richness is maintained in biological communities by framing species interactions as a balance of competition within versus between species. This study uses that theory to investigate whether pollinator sharing affects coexistence dynamics in four co-occurring plants in the genus Clarkia. Determining whether pollinator sharing is detrimental or favorable for flowering plant coexistence hinges on understanding the flower preference and constancy of native bees that specialize on flowers and the quantity of pollen they provide. The diversity and quantity of pollen found on Clarkia's pollinators will be measured with a genetic identification technique (qPCR). These measurements will be used in conjunction with estimates of each plant species' competitive ability to determine whether shared pollinators can change plant fitness and whether the pattern shows a negative frequency dependence. This study will shed light on the role that pollinator sharing can play in promoting the coexistence of flowering plants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diversity in plant communities is integral for supporting the wide diversity of pollinators on earth, and vice versa. Rare plants add to the diversity of plant communities, but due to their rarity are susceptible to recieving either insufficient or incompatible pollen, making seed production and population persistence less likely. Understanding how bee pollinators carry pollen when visiting flowers in diverse communities can tell us about their potential to transfer compatible or incompatible pollen to flowers. One way to do this is to compare the types of pollen on bees to the types of pollen we expect based on the flower community bees were caught in. This helps us understand if bees are visiting rare plants, and if they do, if they are transferring compatible pollen so that those rare plants can make seeds.

In this project, we study bee species that pollinate flowers in the genus Clarkia, in the evening primrose family. Clarkia is named after the explorer William Clark and has about 40 species that mostly live in the western part of the US. Oftentimes, Clarkia live together in multi-species assemblages, where bees visit them. Our questions were: (1) Do bees visit Clarkia randomly when Clarkia live together, or do bees have preferences for common or rare species? and (2) Are bees likely to transfer incompatible pollen between Clarkia species? 

Clarkia pollens look too similar for species identification under the microscope, and our questions required us to quantify the amounts of each Clarkia species bees were collecting. There are currently two ways to identify pollen on bees: either use a miscroscope to identify and count pollen types, or use DNA barcoding techniques to identify the presence or absence of pollen types. Visual identificaiton is quantitative, which is helpful for understanding pollen rarity; a drawback is that pollens can look quite similar, meaning it is hard to identify pollens to species. DNA barcoding has the potential to identify pollens to species, but has two drawbacks: it is not quantitaive, and sometimes can introduce errors which might lead to misidentification.

Outcome 1: We identified places in the genomes of our plants where they were different (SNPs, or single nucelotide polymorphisms) and attempted quantitative PCR (qPCR) to identify and quantify different species in pollen samples from bees. This proved to be ineffective because qPCR probes were not precise enough to distinguish our identified SNP differences between species. Due to issues with precision and costliness, we do not recommend qPCR as a method for identifying and quantifying amplicons in a mixed-species DNA sample.

Outcome 2: We developed a new technique to identify and quantify pollen from bees using molecular techniques that we predict will be useful to many ecological scientists. The new technique, called qAMPseq (quantitative amplicon sequencing), addresses the shortcomings of microscope and metabarcoding techniques. Using DNA samples of mixed-species, it uses PCR and next generation sequencing to identify pollens to species, quantify the amount of each species' pollen in a sample, and decreases the potential for species misidentification. Bee researchers who want to understand pollen movement and use in communities will find this technique helpful for their work, but we also predict that any community ecologist might find qAMPseq of use as it is a quantitative elaboration of common metabarcoding techniques. 

Outcome 3: We found that bees do not visit Clarkia randomly when Clarkia live together, but instead have preferences that are reflected in the pollen they carry. That being said, we also found that bees carry pollen in mixed loads on their bodies, making the likelihood of incompatible pollen transfer high. We find this is more likely for species that more often share pollinators, and less likely for species that do not. We found that most rare species of Clarkia we study was also the least likely to recieve incompatible pollen due to a specialized relationship with a particular bee species. This relationship likely helps its populations persist. This outcome highlights the importance of specialized pollinators for supporting the diversity of bee communities and vice versa.
